Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: A greater respect for grief. More specifically a psychological acceptance of the usefulness of grief and the methods of dealing with loss and trauma. Deeper ability to textually analyze, greater understanding of 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries
I learned some strategies for reading poetry.
I believe I developed a better understanding of mourning and sadness.
I learned a ton about reading and analyzing poetry.

I learned to look more critically at grief poetry and elegy and how they are employed by a wide host of authors to convey different perspectives and meanings. I also feel like I was exposed to a great variety of writing from different authors with different styles through all sorts of historical contexts.

This course made me think about death and loss in so many different ways. I found myself mulling over the topic often outside of class, and was always really fascinated with our discussions of these subjects. Since we're all going to die and we're all going to have people in our life die, I think it's something that should be talked about, and this was such a beautiful and thought provoking way to do so. Additionally, after some time away from it, I really got back into reading poetry again, and was inspired by the texts that we were reading.
I learned about the elegaic tradition and gained insight to analyze and appreciate elegies.
I learned how to critically analyze books and write better essays. I really think my writing improve through this class.
Deep appreciation for elegy and its cultural implications

The Art of Losing helped me learn how to read poems of different forms and from different eras. It also taught me lots of interesting historical information about how people have mourned throughout time. Our field trips to places like the art gallery were very enlightening.
The readings in the class were very interesting and managed to keep me engaged all semester. The discussions were also thought-provoking.
The course material did not follow what was described in YCPS.  It ended up being all poetry, especially elegy, which was not what I expected based on the erroneous course description.

I found the course name misleading; thought it would be about losing a game or overcoming (general) hardships, turned out to be about the aesthetics and process of mourning. 

I would have preferred more opportunities to discuss things with my peers in small groups. I did not like that class discussion was mostly conducted as one large group. 

I do not think my writing improved much because the feedback I received on my assignments wasn't very clear or detailed.

This course had strong teaching and great source material. I loved the way class was so discussion based. I really enjoyed the class visits to museums and other locations around Yale that had relevant material. I have no real complaints about this course.
Strengths are the variation of the material looked at and the professor was just always so engaging and fun in the classroom setting. She really made the class.

Professor Levine did a wonderful job in designing our curriculum and classes, so the material we were working with and learning from always had a lot of variety (in terms of time period, style, culture, subject... everything). She shook up the class by introducing things like films, art, relics, and even a visit to the cemetery, which kept the learning process fresh and exciting. The way the reading responses and papers are designed allows for students to follow their own interests and have a great deal of choice and agency in choosing topics. 

I didn't think that the ghost stories were really necessary or beneficial the course. Other than that, though, I can't really think of any weaknesses. I would take this exact same course again.
The course was engaging and interesting.
I thought it could have been more rigorous, but I really enjoyed the pace of the class.
Deeply enjoyed, strengths: openness for different interpretations and all questions

I loved every reading that Professor Levine chose for this course. We read a healthy mix of poems from multiple eras and perspectives; some of these poems shed light on the experiences of marginalized people and their experiences of sexism, racism, homophobia, etc., which I believed to be important. I also liked the incorporation of history lessons into the course and the emphasis on learning about writers' lives so we can understand them and their work better.
Yes, the course was very interesting.
If the student is okay with dealing with the macabre and dark elegiac processes, then yes. Of course I would recommend it
If you like bohemian poetry, go ahead.  If not, don't take this course.
I would definitely recommend this course to other Yale students, especially if they're looking for an English class that will teach them something new about poetry.
Yes, I would highly recommend this course because of the professor and the critical thinking and constant excitement of the classroom. You just have to have a heart for the more morbid subjects.
Yes, I absolutely would. It's a really engaging, thought provoking, and well designed seminar. I learned a lot.
I would recommend this course to students that are interested in poetry or exploring how loss can be expressed through poetry.
Yes!!!! Wonderful course, accessable teacher, diverse texts, I'm just really thankful for him
I would absolutely recommend this course! I talked about it to my friends constantly; every reading was such a joy to dive into.
